---
title: "Example worksheet"
format: live-html
engine: knitr
---


::: {.cell}

:::



## Non-exercise vs exercise math

Exercises have their own environments. However, they allow use of exmpty spaces to fill in, in addition to hints and solutions. Be aware that you can only use `envir` on exercises, though exercises can access the global environment.


::: {.cell}
```{webr}
2 + 3
```
:::



::: {.cell exercise='math'}
```{webr}
#| exercise: math
2 + 3 - ______
```
:::


## Empty interactive code block

::: {.cell}
```{webr}

```
:::


Or with an exercise


::: {.cell exercise='play'}
```{webr}
#| exercise: play
```
:::


## Non interactive blocks
`webr` cells that are not editable act like normal `r` cells, but they can place objects into the global environment.


::: {.cell edit='false'}
```{webr}
#| edit: false
names <- c("John", "Lily", "Mark", "Anna")
```
:::


## Packages


::: {.cell}
```{webr}
install.packages("dplyr", quiet = TRUE)
library(dplyr)

starwars |>
  filter(height < 100) |>
  select(name, height, mass)
```
:::




## Exercise with hint and solution
Titles for callout blocks can be within the callout div (`{ .callout-tip title="Solution" collapse="false"}`) or a second level heading within the div as with the hints.

Use of an environment to maintain objects created here for use further along.


::: {.cell exercise='assignment' envir='assignment' min-lines='2'}
```{webr}
#| exercise: assignment
#| envir: assignment
#| min-lines: 2
x ______ 5

```
:::


::: { .hint exercise="assignment" }
::: { .callout-note collapse="false" }
## Hint 1

Make sure to use the assignment operator (`<-`)

```r
x <- 5
```
:::
:::

::: { .hint exercise="assignment" }
::: { .callout-note collapse="false" }
## Hint 2

You need to type `Return` or `Enter` after the first line of code to get to the second line of the interactive code block.

:::
:::

::: { .solution exercise="assignment" }
::: { .callout-tip title="Solution" collapse="false"}
To print out the value of `x` to the console, write it on its own line and run the code block.
```r
x <- 5
x
```
:::
:::

## setup


::: {.cell setup='true' exercise='ex_2'}
```{webr}
#| setup: true
#| exercise: ex_2
foo <- 1
bar <- 2
baz <- 3
```
:::



::: {.cell exercise='ex_2'}
```{webr}
#| exercise: ex_2
foo + bar + baz + ______
```
:::


## Tabset

You can also put exercises in a tabset: Make `y` a vector of numbers.

:::: {.panel-tabset}

## Exercise


::: {.cell exercise='ex_4'}
```{webr}
#| exercise: ex_4
y
```
:::


## Hint 1

::: { .hint exercise="ex_4"}
Vectors are created using the `c()`, which stands for combine.

```r
y ______ c(______)
```
:::

## Hint 2

::: { .hint exercise="ex_4"}
Vectors are created using the `c()` function, which stands for combine.

```r
y <- c(______)
```
:::

## Solution

::: { .solution exercise="ex_4" }

```r
y <- c(1, 3, 5, 7, 9)
```
:::

::::

## Andrew Heiss style

Multiply the values by a number.

::: {.panel-tabset}
## {{< fa code >}} Interactive editor

```{webr-r}
c(1, 3, 5, 7, 9)
```

## {{< fa circle-check >}} Solution

```r
c(1, 3, 5, 7, 9) * 2
```

:::
